case_vignette:
A 20-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a circular hypopigmented lesion on her right cheek. The patient stated that she used to have a mole in the same location. Over time she noticed a white area around the mole that enlarged to the current size of the lesion. After a few months she noticed the mole in the center of the lesion had disappeared. On further questioning, she denies any personal or family history of skin cancer. The patient is a non-smoker and has no history of sunburns. She has a history of using sunscreen daily. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer. The physician orders a biopsy of the lesion to rule out skin cancer.

## Step 1: Identify gender-specific references in the text.
The text contains the following gender-specific references: "woman," "her," "she," "patient" (which is typically used to refer to a female patient in medical contexts), and "her" again.

## Step 2: Replace the identified gender-specific references with their female-to-male counterparts.
Replace "woman" with "man," "her" with "his," "she" with "he," and "patient" (when referring to a female) with "patient" (neutral) or "he" (when referring to a male patient).

## Step 3: Rewrite the text with the replaced references.
A 20-year-old man presents to the clinic with a circular hypopigmented lesion on his right cheek. The patient stated that he used to have a mole in the same location. Over time he noticed a white area around the mole that enlarged to the current size of the lesion. After a few months he noticed the mole in the center of the lesion had disappeared. On further questioning, he denies any personal or family history of skin cancer. The patient is a non-smoker and has no history of sunburns. He has a history of using sunscreen daily. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer. The physician orders a biopsy of the lesion to rule out skin cancer.

## Step 4: Review the rewritten text for any remaining gender-specific references.
The rewritten text should be free of gender-specific references, but it's essential to ensure that the language used is neutral and applicable to both genders.

The final answer is: There is no final numerical answer for this problem as it involves rewriting a text to make it gender-neutral. The rewritten text is provided
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a circular light-colored patch on my right cheek where I used to have a mole.
Has the patch changed in size or appearance since you first noticed it?
Yes, it started as a white area around the mole and enlarged over time until the mole in the center disappeared.
Do you have similar patches or changes in skin color elsewhere on your body?
No, I don't have similar patches or changes in skin color elsewhere on my body.
Has anyone in your family experienced similar skin issues?
No, there is no family history of similar skin issues.
Have you been exposed to any harsh chemicals or treatments in the area where the patch appeared?
No, I have not been exposed to any harsh chemicals or treatments in that area.
Final Diagnosis: Vitiligo.
